name.description: Please insert the name of the person filling up the questionnaire.
name.title: 1.1 Your name

enumNames: Physics of the CMS-Totem Precision Proton Spectometer (PPS)
wg.title: 1.3. Working group

cadi_id.description: If a CADI entry is available, please make sure you fill it correctly, as an email will be sent to the review Hypernews associated to the CADI line. If no CADI entry is available, please provide below the title and applicable references (analysis note numbers, etc.)
cadi_id.title: 1.4. CADI entry number, if available

title_references.description: If you don't have a CADI entry number yet, please fill this field with the title of the analysis and the applicable references (Analysis Note numbers, etc.)
title_references.title: 1.5. Title and references (if CADI number not available)

next_deadline_date.description: Please cite the preapproval date (if it has been set), or the closest next deadline (approval, freezing, etc.). It defaults to one week (assuming you fill it when freezing for preapproval)
next_deadline_date.title: 1.6. Next deadline date (typically, preapproval date)

analysis_summary.description: Please describe briefly the analysis (what is being measured or sought for, what dataset, and how)
analysis_summary.title: 1.7. Three-line summary of the analysis

related_cadi_ids.description: Please include here earlier versions of this analysis, if applicable. Please point out all relevant similarities/differences.
related_cadi_ids.title: 1.8. CADI entry numbers of analysis with same/similar statistical treatment

aware_twiki.description: The main Statistics Committee TWiki page. The Frequently Asked Questions. The statistics-related references.
aware_twiki.title: 2.1. Are you aware that the Statistics Committee has a TWiki page which links a number of short documents describing recommendations for statistical techniques?

aware_sc_answer.description: You can send your questions to the Statistics Discussions Hypernews forum, or to the Committee's mailing list cms-statistics-committee@cern.ch.
aware_sc_answer.title: 2.2. Are you aware that the Statistics Committee will make an effort to promptly answer your question on statistics issues?

hn_subscription.title: 2.3. Have you subscribed yet to the Statistics Discussions Hypernews forum (if not, we suggest that you do)?

sc_interaction.title: 2.4. Have you interacted with the Statistics Committee in the past (via email, HN, or in person) to discuss an issue with a CMS analysis?

aware_sc_meetings.title: 2.5. Are you aware that the Statistics Committee meets regularly (Vidyo only; look for announcement in Statistics Discussions HN forum) and that everybody is welcome to participate?

read_sc_twiki.title: 3.1. Have you read the SC TWiki page on MVA recommendations?

mva_use.description: If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next page of the questionnaire
mva_use.title: 3.2. Are you using a multi-variate discriminant in your data analysis to discriminate between signal and background?

options.title: Select the software from the list

other.title: If the software is not listed above, please specify it here

options.title: Select the classifier from the list

other.title: If the classifier is not listed above, please specify it here

clf.title: 3.4. What type of classifier do you use?

enum: We cut on the output to improve S/B
We fit the output distribution to get the signal fraction

options.title: Select the use case from the list

other.title: If the use case is not listed above, please specify it here

mva.title: 3.5. How do you make use of the MVA output in the analysis?

options.title: Select the check you performed, from the list

other.title: If the check is not listed above, please specify it here

input.title: 3.6. How have you checked that the input variables, including their dependencies, are well-modeled?

enum: We study the correlation matrix between the input variables
We also study dependence beyond linear correlation (please specify details in the text field below)

options.title: Select the study you performed from the list

other.title: If the study you performed is not on the list, please specify it here

correlation.title: 3.7. Do you study the correlations and dependencies between the input variables?

enum: Yes, we use the correlation matrix and remove highly correlated variables
No, we keep the complete list
Other (please specify in the field below
options.title: Select the way you select the input variables

other.title: If you select the input variables in a different way, please specify it here

input_selection.title: 3.8. How do you select the input variables? Do you perform any pruning of your initial list of input variables, based on the correlations or dependencies between the input variables?

enum: Yes, but this does not apply to my analysis
Yes, I make training samples large enough and I checked that this does not occur
Yes, and I need to check whether this applies to my analysis
Other (please specify in the field below)
options.title: Select the way you deal with this issue

other.title: If none of the above, please specify here

mva_techniques.title: 3.9. Are you aware that some MVA techniques may classify data events as very signal-like if any of their variables take values in regions where the background training samples have no events?

enum: Does not apply: we have only one background process
No (please specify what you do in the "Additional Comments" field)
options.title: Select the way you mix the samples

sample_mix.title: 3.10. When training with more than one background, do you mix all samples in the proportions you expect in data?

enum: We do not perform any check
We divide the sample in two subsamples: one used exclusively for training, and the other for all subsequent analysis (optimizations, analysis plots, measurements using the discriminant, etc.)
We do perform checks (please specify in "Additional comments")
options.title: Select the way you deal with overtraining

overtraining.title: 3.11. How do you make sure you are not affected by overtraining?

enum: We do not perform any checks
Does not apply: we have only one background process
options.title: Select the way you treat the check

robustness_check.title: 3.12. Do you perform the following robustness check? Train two (or more) MVAs starting from different random sets of weights, and then look at the event-by-event correlation in the final output. It should be very diagonal.

analysis_fitting.description: If the answer is "No", please proceed with Section 5.
analysis_fitting.title: 4.1. Does the analysis include fitting of data distributions?

analysis_fitting_specifics.description: If you perform many different fits, please use for the following questions the "Additional Comments" fields for specifying details
analysis_fitting_specifics.title: 4.2. Which fits are you performing in your analysis?

fitting_model.title: 4.4. How do you choose the fitting model?

other.title: 4.5.1. What drove you to this particular choice?

stats.title: 4.5. Which test statistic are you using to perform the fit(s)?

use_options.description: If the answer is "No", please explain in "Additional Comments" why you deem such tests unnecessary for the fits in your analysis. Otherwise, please provide some details of how this test is performed, in "Additional Comments".
use_options.title: Select whether you perform a GoF test

gof.title: 4.6. Do you perform a goodness-of-fit test for the fit(s)?

enum: No, but we do not use the uncertainty returned by the fit anyway
Yes, and the result is that the method is unbiased
Yes, and there are some deviations we account for (please specify in "Additional Comments")
options.title: Do you check it?

pd_check.title: 4.7. Do you check that the pull distribution in toy experiments is distributed as expected for an unbiased method (mean 0, width 1)?

enum: Does not apply: we do not use the parameters/uncertainties elsewhere
options.title: Are you accounting for the covariance matrix?

covariance_matrix.title: 4.8. In case you are using the returned parameters in other parts of your analysis: are you accounting for the covariance matrix (error and off-diagonal correlation terms) of the parameter uncertainties?

enum: Does not apply: we do not perform this kind of fitting
We perform robustness checks to show that we are insensitive to the choice of the functional form.
We tried different options and assign a systematic uncertainty from the difference.
options.title: Select the way you choose your functional form

func_form.title: 4.9. In case you perform a fit to the background shape with a function: How do you choose the functional form?

enum: Does not apply: we do not use such a function for fitting
We choose what looks more or less OK
We perform robustness checks to show that we are insensitive to this choice
We tried different options and chose the most "conservative" one
We applied a formal decision procedure (such as Fisher F-Test, LR test, please specify in "Additional Comments")
options.title: Select the way you choose the number of parameters

nop.title: 4.10. In case you perform a fit using a functional form which exists for many different number of parameters (such as polynomials): How are you choosing the number of parameters?

enum: Yes, but we do not use the uncertainty
Yes, and we check that the error calculation is robust anyways
Yes, and we trust the errors from the fitter without further checks
options.title: Select the answer that applies

close_physical_boundaries.title: 4.11. Are any of the parameters returned by the fit close (less than 3 sigma) to their physical or pre-defined boundary?

limits_on_parameters.description: If the answer is "No", please proceed with Section 6. If the answer is "Yes", then in many cases the confidence interval estimation will involve data fitting (e.g. fitting with a signal plus background model); in this case, please fill also Section 4.
limits_on_parameters.title: 5.1. Does the analysis include the setting of limits on some parameter or placing a confidence interval on some parameter? *

enum: We will only cite a limit
We will only cite a two-sided interval
We will decide that after looking at data
Does not apply: we use a unified interval construction approach (Feldman-Cousins)
options.title: Select the answer that applies

two_sided_select.title: 5.2. Will you cite a limit or a two-sided confidence interval?

enum: Does not apply: we do not perform limit computation
aware_agreement_cms_atlas.title: 5.3. Are you aware of the agreement between ATLAS and CMS regarding limit setting, which — among other things — requires the CLs method for Higgs and SUSY analyses?

enum: Does not apply: we do not perform limit computation
aware_sc_support.title: 5.4. Are you aware that the Statistics Committee provides support and a simple recipe to include the derivation of Feldman-Cousins confidence intervals in RooStats jobs that are currently used to compute CLs limits?

enum: Does not apply: we do not use Bayesian methods
aware_bayesian.title: 5.5. If you are using a Bayesian technique, are you aware that the SC recommends to perform a prior sensitivity analysis, both on the PDFs of parameters describing the systematic uncertainties (nuisance parameters) and on the PDF of the parameter to be estimated?

enum: Bayesian limits/intervals, with a flat priori for the parameter of interest
Bayesian limits/intervals, with a reference prior for the parameter of interest

options.title: Mark the approach(es) you are using
Mark the software(s) you are using

confidence_interval_tools.title: 5.7. What software tool are you using for your confidence interval calculations?

enum: Does not apply: the construction does not make use of a test statistic.
Likelihood ratio in which nuisance parameters and signal cross section are all fixed to a nominal value ("LEP-like").
Profile likelihood ratio in which nuisance parameters are varied in the maximization and the signal cross section parameter is fixed ("Tevatron-like").

Profile likelihood ratio modified for upper limits in which nuisance parameters are varied in the nominator and denominator. The signal cross section mu is fixed to the currently tested point mu* in the nominator and is varied but constrained to 0 <= mu < mu* in the denominator (sometimes called the "LHC-like" test statistic; this is used in the Higgs combination).
options.title: Select the answer that applies

other.title: 5.8.1. If you chose "other" in the previous question, please specify the test statistic used here.

frequentist_stats.title: 5.8. In the case of frequentist/CLs confidence interval construction: which test statistic do you use?

cross_check.title: 5.9.1. If you choose "Yes" in the previous question, did you make a cross check with toys, e.g. checking the agreement of toy and asymptotics based upper limits for some exemplary values of new physics model parameters such as the mass of a new particle?

asymptotic_formulae.title: 5.9. Do you use asymptotic formulae from the paper https://arxiv.org/abs/1007.1727v3 for your confidence interval estimations?

enum: Does not apply: the method does not require toys
Nuisance parameters are sampled from their priors
A fit to data is performed, and the fitted nuisance parameter values are used for toy data generation (this is sometimes called "bootstrapping")
options.title: Select the answer that applies

toy_data.title: 5.10. In the case toy data is generated as part of the procedure—e.g. to determine the test statistic distribution or to compute the expected limit / expected limit bands—please specify how the nuisance parameter are chosen for the toys:

enum: Does not apply: we do not cite a limit / only cite a limit on the cross section itself
We do not account for theory uncertainties
We vary the theory prediction by one sigma up/down and cite the most "conservative" limit
We introduce an additional nuisance parameter in the statistical model which modifies the cross section within the theory uncertainty
We perform a Bayesian integration over the theory prediction and cite the prior-averaged limit
options.title: Select the answer that applies

limit_conversion.title: 5.11. In case you convert a limit on a signal cross section into a limit on the mass (or another parameter; we call it "mass" here): how do you account for the theory error on the signal cross section?

discovery_twiki.description: Page on Search Procedures, page on Sensitivity Calculations, page on Look-Elsewhere Effect.
discovery_twiki.title: 6.1. Have you read the discovery-related TWiki pages on Search Procedures, Sensitivity Calculations, and Look-Elsewhere Effect (if applicable)?

discovery_related_statements.description: If the answer is "No", please proceed with Section 7.
discovery_related_statements.title: 6.2. Does the analysis include discovery-related statements, such as citing p-values of the null hypothesis or a "significance"?

enum: Likelihood ratio in which all nuisance parameters and parameter of interest are fixed to a nominal value
Profile likelihood ratio in which nuisance parameters and parameter of interest are varied in the maximisation
options.title: Select the answer that applies

test_statistic.title: 6.3. To evaluate the p-value(s) of the null hypothesis, what test statistic was used?

enum: Does not apply: we only look for one signal which is completely specified (i.e., mass, width, etc. is known)
options.title: Select the answer that applies

look_elsewhere_effect.title: 6.4. Do you account for the look-elsewhere effect?

is_used.description: If the answer is "No", please proceed with Section 8.
is_used.title: 7.1. Is unfolding used in parts of the analysis?

twiki.title: 7.2. Have you read the SC TWiki page on recommendations for unfolding techniques?

correlation_neglect.title: 7.3. Are you aware that the SC discourages the use of bin-by-bin unfolding, or correction factors, and in general on techniques neglecting correlations?

enum: Generalized Matrix inversion with Tikhonov regularization (SVD by Höcker and Kartvelishvili)
Generalized Matrix inversion with Tikhonov regularization (TUnfold)
options.title: Select the answer that applies

techniques.title: 7.4. Which unfolding technique are you using?

generalization.title: 7.6. We recommend to try unfolding without regularization, have you tested this?

response_matrix_condition.title: 7.7. The condition number of the response matrix (it can be determined using e.g. the TDecompSVD class in ROOT) can be a good indicator of whether regularization is needed or not. What is its value?

parameter.title: 7.8. If you have performed unfolding with regularization, by which objective criterion have you chosen the regularization parameter (number of iterations in case of D'Agostini or other iterative unfolding methods)?

options.title: 7.9.1. Have you used toy experiments to verify the coverage of the unfolded uncertainties?

comments.title: 7.9.2. Which other checks have you performed for validation (e.g. comparison with other techniques, unfolding reweighted MCs, unfolding one fully simulated MC using a MC with a different physics model for the response matrix and regularization, etc.)?

enum: Yes (please describe the outcome in "Additional Comments")
options.title: Select the answer that applies

bottom_line_test.title: 7.9.3. Have you performed the bottom line test?

enum: Does not apply: We do not use event weights for data.
We first apply the event weight to get the new (weighted) "observed" spectrum, which is then unfolded.
The unfolding is based on the spectrum built from unweighted events; any weight is handled as part of the smearing matrix.
options.title: Select the answer that applies

weights_applied.title: 7.10. In case you apply weights to the number of observed (real data) events, e.g. to correct for trigger prescales:

histogram.title: 7.11.1. The unfolded histogram and its total covariance matrix

response_matrix.title: 7.11.2. The response matrix K as a coloured 2D histogram

public_info.title: 7.11. Which information do you intend to make publicly available?

twiki.title: 8.1. Have you read the SC recommendation TWiki pages on systematic uncertainties?

statistic_uncertainties.title: 8.2. Have you considered that systematic uncertainties constrained by sideband measurements in the data, and whose estimate thus depends on the size of the analyzed dataset, should be treated as statistical uncertainties?

systematic_effect.title: 8.3. If including a systematic effect as nuisance parameter in the model, are you aware that the SC recommends the use of Gamma or Log-Normal priors instead of truncated Gaussians?

uncertainty.title: 8.4.1. Are you deriving a systematic uncertainty on your main measurement from the level of agreement you observe in the cross-check?

failure.title: 8.4.2. What would you have done if the cross-check failed (e.g. p-value below 0.01, or other pre-defined criterion)?

cross_check.title: 8.4. Does your analysis include "cross-checks" of your method, e.g. the verification of a technique on a subsidiary set of data?

enum: No, we do not perform template morphing
options.title: Select the answer that applies

template_morphing.title: 8.5. Do you use "template morphing" in you analysis, e.g. to model a systematic uncertainty in the statistical model?

enum: You checked that the differences between the predictions using the central eigenvectors of different PDFs are significantly larger than the uncertainties of each PDF set separately and you use an envelope of PDFs recommended by PDF4LHC page: https://twiki.cern.ch/twiki/bin/viewauth/CMS/PDFatCMS
Most PDFs result in very similar predictions in the full phase space of your analysis and you use the PDF which describes the data best and estimate uncertainties using its eigenvectors
You use the method of META PDFs (applies only to searches)
You use the method of Compressed Monte Carlo (CMC) PDFs (applies only to searches)
options.title: Select the answer that applies

pdf_uncertainty.title: 9.1. How do you estimate the PDF uncertainty on your measurement, e.g. effects on the acceptance?

use.description: If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next question (9.3).
use.title: Select the answer that applies

enum: Calculated the correlation coefficients or performed a phenomenological analysis comparing predictions using different PDFs / varying QCD parameters
Used HERAFitter to perform a full PDF extraction
options.title: 9.2.1. How do you estimate the sensitivity of Your observable to QCD parameters/PDFs?

hepdata.title: 9.2.2. Do you plan to provide Your measurement to HEPDATA including correlation matrices to be used by PDF groups? (The PDF forum provides support for pushing measurements to HEPDATA.)

sm.title: 9.2. Do you perform a SM measurement to test QCD or to determine SM parameters like proton PDFs, heavy-quark masses, or the strong coupling constant alpha_s?

enum: Multiple orders are used (please explain in "Additional Comments")
options.title: Select the answer that applies

order.title: 9.3.1. Does the order of the PDF you use (LO, NLO, NNLO) correspond to the order of the calculation you are using?

enum: Latest sets from all PDF groups (ABM, CT, HERAPDF, MMHT, NNPDF)
PDFs listed on the web page of the CMS PDF forum
Earlier PDF sets not derived with LHC data (please explain in "Additional comments")
options.title: Select the answer that applies

selection.title: 9.3.2. How did you choose the PDFs to compare your measurements to the theory prediction?

citations.title: 9.3.3. Did you properly cite every PDF set employed even when used only within the context of the PDF4LHC recommendation or CMS or META PDFs?

uncertainty.title: 9.3.4. Do you estimate the PDF uncertainty on your prediction using the procedure described in the publication of the particular PDF you use?

pdf.title: 9.3. Comparison of Your measurement to theory predictions for the interpretation of the results:

parton_distribution_functions.description: Information about the use of parton distribution functions of the proton (PDF in this section) in your analysis. CMS PDF forum provides help for those topics and can be contacted via HyperNews or mailing list at TWiki page.
parton_distribution_functions.title: 9. Parton Distribution Functions

enum: We do not perform a blind analysis: we didn't see how to do that practically
We do not perform a blind analysis
options.title: Select the answer that applies

blind_analysis.title: 10.1. Do you perform a blind analysis? If so, can you succinctly describe what was done?

enum: Does not apply: we do not perform a combination
options.title: Select the answer that applies

combined_measurements.title: 10.2. In case you combine measurements in your analysis: what method is used?

enum: Yes, this applies (please specify how in "Additional Comments")
options.title: Select the answer that applies

analysis_correlations.title: 10.3. In case you use the results of another CMS analysis: how did you treat correlations from common systematic uncertainties and from potential overlap in the datasets?

enum: Almost nothing is decided, we still expect major changes
We already tried some methods, but not yet taken a final decision on which one to use
Decision has been taken on methods, but still need some improvements (such as refining an implementation, etc.)
options.title: Select the answer that applies

feedback_not_frozen.title: 11.1. What statistical element of your analysis is not yet frozen (what changes can be expected)?

comments.title: 11.2. Do you have any additional comment related to the analysis? Is there a statistic-related element of your analysis not covered by this questionnaire?

suggestions.title: 11.3. Do you have a suggestion for improving this questionnaire? Do you have a suggestion for improving interaction with the CMS Statistics Committee in general or documentation of statistical recommendations?
